https://metro.co.uk/2021/07/02/xr-activi.title: XR activist won’t pay tax as council ‘hasn’t done enough to stop climate change’
https://metro.co.uk/2021/07/02/xr-activi.text:
An Extinction Rebellion activist is withholding thousands in council tax because she thinks Leicester City Council is not using its money well enough to tackle climate change.
Karen Wilden could face jail time if she does not pay the £2,521 she owes. She was summoned to appear before city magistrates this week and says she has been ‘harassed’ by bailiffs since she stopped paying in 2019.
Despite this, she says she plans to refuse to pay tax until council leaders ‘demonstrate that they are seeking to listen to and represent Leicester people and the environment, at a real and relevant level’.
Extinction Rebellion encourages its members to participate in an Earth Tax Strike as part of its ‘money disobedience’ campaign.
The group believes the Government does not use taxes ‘to keep us safe’ and instead puts public money ‘into fossil fuel subsidies, condition-free bailouts for polluting industries, and HS2, an aviation shuttle service that is destroying nature’.
Leicester City Council declared a climate emergency in January 2019 but Ms Wilden said this ‘seemed like an empty gesture’.
She went on: ‘I believe that as individuals we should contribute to the welfare of the community and the wider world.
‘However, in my view, Leicester City Council is not doing either of these things to a standard or with the degree of urgency, that the planet and the public requires.
‘We are in a Climate and Ecological Emergency. Our councils need to behave accordingly.’
She accused the council of cutting down trees to build roads, using harmful chemicals to spray verges and shredding plastic rubbish in parks by not litter-picking before mowing.
But Leicester City Council told LeicestershireLive it is one of ‘the most progressive councils in the country when it comes to addressing the climate emergency’.
Deputy mayor Adam Clarke said: ‘We have had several constructive meetings with Extinction Rebellion locally and sympathise with many of their concerns about climate change.
‘But everyone has to pay their council tax, which funds vital services – including our local response to the climate emergency.
‘Our commitments include extending the city’s tree canopy and tree numbers, fitting energy efficient measures to council homes and schools, and investing heavily in walking, cycling and low-carbon public transport, including our new ebike share scheme, which will be the largest of its type in the country.
‘Collecting debts such as council tax takes resources away from other services.
‘I would urge Extinction Rebellion to continue dialogue with us rather than taking this counter-productive approach’.
